title: Why Your New iPhone 17 / 17 Pro / 17 Pro Max Deserves a Wi-Fi 7 Router
author: RouterHaus
excerpt: Apple’s iPhone 17 lineup supports Wi-Fi 7 and 320 MHz channels—BUT you won’t feel the speed or latency gains unless your router can match it (6 GHz, 320 MHz, MLO).
content: iPhone 17 / 17 Pro / 17 Pro Max bring Wi-Fi 7 with 320 MHz channels and Multi-Link Operation. That means faster AirDrop, quicker iCloud backups, and lower-lag streaming—if your router supports Wi-Fi 7 on 6 GHz. Still on Wi-Fi 5/6? Your phone falls back and you lose the benefits. This post shows why upgrading the router unlocks your new iPhone’s speed, what specs to buy (320 MHz, MLO, 2.5G+ ports), and how to set it up right.

title: Mesh vs. Single Router (2025): Which Actually Fits Your Home?
author: RouterHaus
excerpt: Do you really need a mesh system, or will a single high-end Wi-Fi 7 router cover your home? We break it down by square footage, layout, and device load.
content: Mesh isn’t always the answer. For apartments and smaller homes, a single Wi-Fi 7 router may outperform a 3-node mesh. But for multi-story layouts and ranch-style homes with tough materials, mesh with wired backhaul is the way to go. Here’s how to decide.

title: How to Build a Rock-Solid Work-From-Home Network (2025)
author: RouterHaus
excerpt: Video calls, uploads, and VPNs demand reliability more than raw speed. Here’s how to design a home network that won’t drop mid-meeting.
content: A work-from-home network must prioritize latency, coverage, and device contention control. That means using Wi-Fi 7 for modern devices, wiring desks where possible, enabling QoS, and isolating IoT on guest Wi-Fi or VLANs. This post walks you through a blueprint for apartments, ranches, and multi-story homes.

title: Why Range Still Matters: Beating Dead Zones in Modern Homes (2025)
author: RouterHaus
excerpt: Fast specs don’t fix weak coverage. Dead zones are solved by placement, mesh nodes, and wiring—not just a ‘powerful’ router.
content: Modern Wi-Fi 7 routers boast 320 MHz channels and multi-link operation, but if your office or bedroom has −70 dBm signal, performance tanks. This guide shows how to identify dead zones, understand how walls and materials block signals, and apply practical fixes—from router placement to mesh with wired backhaul.

title: Too Many Devices? How Bandwidth Splits in a 50-Device Home (2025)
author: RouterHaus
excerpt: Smart homes with 30–50 devices are now common. Learn how MU-MIMO, OFDMA, and QoS keep calls smooth and streaming stable when everything is online.
content: It’s normal for a home to have 40+ devices online: phones, TVs, cameras, consoles, smart speakers, thermostats. Without proper airtime management, everything slows. Wi-Fi 7 routers with MU-MIMO, OFDMA, and QoS prevent congestion. Here’s how bandwidth is split, and how to make sure your network doesn’t crumble under load.

title: Gaming Latency & Jitter Explained: A 10-Minute Fix for Low-Lag Wi-Fi 7
author: RouterHaus
excerpt: Cut ping spikes and packet loss fast. We explain latency vs. jitter in plain English and show the 10-minute setup that fixes it on Wi-Fi 7.
content: Lag isn’t just about Mbps—it’s about latency and jitter. In 10 minutes: place your router/node right, enable 6 GHz + MLO, turn on Smart QoS/SQM, and wire your console/PC if possible. We also recommend Wi-Fi 7 routers that excel at stable latency—see our picks on kits.html.

title: The Ultimate Guide to Structured Wiring for New Home Construction (2025)
author: RouterHaus
excerpt: Definitive pillar for builders and new homeowners: where to run Ethernet and fiber, AP pre-wires, panel spec, and a ready-to-bid checklist.
content: Pre-wire right at rough-in: home-run Cat6a, single-mode fiber from demarc, ceiling AP drops with PoE, and a ventilated low-voltage closet. Use our room-by-room drop table and bid checklist, then funnel to consult.html for stamped plans and AP layouts.
